ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Karen Petersen
Karen Petersen
Karen Peterson
Both Annie and Karen were great. Accessible, even with their busy schedules, and knew their stuff.
Interacted with both Annie and Karen.
Both Annie and Karen, pretty equally.
Karen Petersen.
n/a
About the same
Annie O'Sullivan and Karen. Both are great!

Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  The teaching assistants with whom I interacted were in fact Annie O'Sullivan and Karen Petersen -- both of these TAs were very helpful in TA sessions that were held multiple days every week!Troy Hill's role was solely to assistant on one field trip. This survey only allows me to select Troy Hill's name, rather than the two core TAs mentioned above...

Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy wasnÂ´t the TA for this course but IÂ´ll give this advice because I know he wants to teach: just be a bit more sensative to the fact that people have different backgrounds and may not have -what are to you- the basic things down.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Professor Anisfeld is a very organized professor who clearly puts a lot of time into teaching this course. I was impressed by his dedication to teaching and to working with students outside of class to make sure material was well understood.

Overall this was a really excellent class.One suggestion: At times the formulas that we would need for homework assignments were hard to find in the printed notes. Some way of highlighting them better might be useful--perhaps a common form of presentation, or just making them larger on the slide. In addition, at times not all the variables in the formula were explained in class--it would be helpful if a definition of each variable were included with some detail in the slide.Otherwise, great class and wonderful explanations.

This course was challenging for people like me, with no prior background. I really had to try hard to get my mind back into a science-oriented mode. It hadn't happened since high school. But that's part of the reason why I came to FES, and this course accomplished exactly what I was hoping it would. Overall I'm very happy with the course.
This course should be mandatory for all students.
Shimi is awesome. But he tries to cover a LOT. Not too much, but I would've gotten completely lost if I hadn't recently taken several related science undergrad classes.
It is hard to cover so much material in a semester, but by the end of it I was surprised at how much I was able to pick up. IÂ´m very glad I took this course.
Question 6: applies to both TA's
Please see below.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Office hour review sessions, where help was provided on the problem sets --without this assistance, these problem sets would have been very difficult.

I really liked that participation was encouraged and was facilitated through the clickers.Also the approach of using class response questions to solidify and test our knowledge was very helpful.I also appreciated the chance to explore a topic of interest to me through the paper summary. This enabled me to look into a subject that I felt I needed to understand for other courses but that couldn't be covered in depth in this course.
I thought the readings posted on ClassesV2 were very helpful (except that they trailed off towards the end of the semester).
We went over a range of topics, all of which I am sure will be built upon in more specialized classes.
Shimi is a very good teacher; he has very high standards, but the course is very rewarding if you put the time and effort in to learn the material. I felt like I learned a lot in this course!!

Shimi's lecture style is great, very engaging and clearly thought out. Shimi is the most accessible and responsive professor I have had at FES. He clearly cares a great deal about teaching, and it shows, he's excellent.I also really like his sense of humor.
Material was interesting. Well-organized.
-Shimi being open to questions during class-TAs helpful during office hours-Work and tests felt very reasonable and asked reasonable questions of students, but were still challenging
Really useful and valuable information. Shimi is the best part of the course - he is clearly interested and dedicated and one of the best professors at FES.
Shimi is awesome during office hours. He's pushed me and everyone, but was helpful and nice while doing it.
The breadth of material. Felt like a good review.

The course material flowed smoothly from concept to concept and the overall delivery was done in a way that maintained interest. Use of the 'clicker' during class was a big plus that helped keep students engaged.

Professor Anisfeld was very responsive to questions asked by students in class. I really liked that he posed several questions during every session that we answered on the spot using clickers. This not only kept students engaged but was a very effective way for Professor Anisfeld and for students themselves to gauge how well they were understanding the new material. I also thought the class response questions due 24 hours after each class and the article summary were very effective and useful teaching devices.
A good amount of breadth and depth

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I worry about retention -- all problem sets are focused on quantitative calculations that I expect not to remember to be able to do in a few months after the course is over. Given that this is an intro class, more focus should be on core *concepts* rather than applying various formulas and conversion factors.
Please see above re: clarity of formulas in notes.

I think we would have benefited from discussing the readings in class a bit more. For example, once or twice during the semester we could discuss in class a journal article or research paper that was assigned in the days before. The written summary was useful, but this could be another good way to get experience understanding research.

I felt like this course was structured with the idea that all (or most) of the students would go to office hours most weeks to get help on the problem sets--I feel like they weren't really designed so that we could do them on our own. I appreciate that one of the TAs or Shimi was always available to help, but I wasn't a big fan of this format. If problem sets are going to be difficult (even if they are easier than past years!) it almost seems like the course would benefit from having a weekly section.

Staying on top of class response questions was challenging. Too much going on, when you combine class responses with problem sets, exams, etc. And I feel like too much grading weight was placed on class responses vis a vis the other things that took much more work (like problem sets).
-Thought it would have been interesting to have clicker questions answered by students who had answered correctly - corrected, if necessary, by Shimi
Nothing.

I feel that the course covers too much material. I would have preferred to cover water, atmosphere and soil topics only, and perhaps leave an introduction to energy and climate change to another course entirely.
Sometimes I found problem set questions to be worded in a way that could be interpreted in more ways than one... which would lead to more than one correct answer.

In a survey course like this I think it is good - to the extent possible - I think it is good for professors to try to not overemphasize their area of specialization. It was a bit frustrating to have all roads lead back to pKaÂ´s but I will admit that the repetition was good at helping me retain the material.

I would have liked even more discussion of the practical applicability of the course concepts and exercises in how they may be useful in solving problems.In a couple of cases, some key skills were never fully developed in the lectures, but needed in the problem sets (e.g. chemistry). This was very frustrating.

I honestly felt that there was too much material covered in this course in terms of how many different topics were covered. On a couple of different occasions I found myself getting frustrated that because there was such a breadth of material covered in this course, we were not able to go into as much depth as I would have liked. In my mind, the whole value of studying science is understanding how and why things work the way that they do. It is very difficult to teach a "survey" science course that touches on so many different topics in such a short period of time. Since I understand this course to be the only basic science class for science and non-science students alike, I would advocated for it being offered as a two part course. Half of the topics could be covered in the fall and half in the spring, both in greater detail. That way not only would students feel like they had a more technical (rather than quite basic) understanding of the material but they could also choose which topics were most relevant to their professional interest and therefore only take one or take both of the two courses.
Provide notes for the last part of the course because the slides were not detailed enough and the book did not cover all of the lectures.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: n/a
n/a
Very useful, especially for hard problem sets.
Thought it was great. Would have liked another field trip, if possible.
N/A
n/a
IÂ´ve never in my life had a professor who was more accessible and willing to help. It was very surprising and so helpful.
Fine.

There were no real discussion sections but attending the weekly help sessions were fairly critical to succeeding in this course. The TAs and Professor Anisfeld were both very effective in explaining concepts during these sessions.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: n/a
Karen Peterson and Annie O'Sullivan were both extremely approachable, available when you needed and patient when going over topics.
Both were responsive and helpful. Assignments were graded in a timely fashion.
Both Annie and Karen were super friendly, helpful during sessions, and available to answer questions.
n/a... I pretty much went to Shimi for everything, including office hours. I simply didn't have much exposure with them.

At times, the TAs seemed a bit too reluctant when asked for help. Also they seemed to only have superficial knowledge of many of the topics, e.g. just enough to get the homework done but not enough to explain a concept clearly and thoroughly.
Both Annie O'Sullivan and Karen were great TAs. I talked to them both at different office hours and they were patient and effective in explaining concepts.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  I think Troy could focus more on starting from the basics and then building up.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Really excellent background for other MF courses, especially soils (which I was taking at the same time and understood much more fully as a result of this class).

The course's material is not directly related to my program and goals at FES, but I still maintain that the course was worthwhile. For one thing, I'm almost positive that I will encounter the chemistry again in the future. More broadly, it was great to get practice in scientific and quantitative reasoning, despite the course's broad, introductory nature.
Great foundation on which to build more specialized knowledge. Wish I had taken it in my first year at FES.
Additional understandings of physical science underpinnings as I move into a more policy-oriented phase. Some quantitative&conceptual understandings of more complex physical systems.
This course is a good refresher/ introduction for environmental chemistry, soils, hydrology, etc. that will be useful for futures courses that I may take in those topics.

My interest is energy and Shimi tied energy into the class. So I was happy. Also, he began the class with a "clicker" question. He immediately saw that most of use were interested in "business& the environment" or "energy" and knew that it should be included in the class.
I agree with the powers that be thatthis is a good foundation class to take and IÂ´m glad I took it in my first semester.

I think this course is very important for understanding basic environmental issues to a reasonable degree of scientific depth. It covered many areas that I'm sure I won't get in other courses as I become more focused on a particular specialization.
This was the course I was most eager to take this fall because an understanding of the science behind environmental issues is critical to any profession in this field.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Requirement for degree.
I took this because it was listed as a Foundations course.
To satisfy the "hydrology" requirement for the MF. Also for general knowledge.
see above
Build some technical knowledge.
See Q20.
Primarily because it'sa Foundation, but also because it's of interest to me.
I wanted a stronger foundation in the sciences ( I come from a policy background) and this course certainly provided a good running start.
Required foundation
Please see above.
For an introduction to hydrology and to better understand soil and climate science - would fill an education gap

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: See response to Question 17. I worry about retention.
Yes! I learned a great deal from this class.
Yes.
Yes
Yes, definitely!
Yes
Yes! Liked the article review as a "practical application" of knowledge... one more in place of a problem set could have been helpful.
Far exceeded expectations.
Yes, but it actually exceeded expectations.
The class was different than I was expecting. The things we focused on were not exactly the things I was expecting to learn, but I certainly took away quite a bit.

I was very eager to solidify my comprehension of the scientific principles underlying environmental issues but as previously mentioned, I really wish this course had gone into greater depth rather than just providing a survey of many different topics. Although I appreciated the exposure to a lot of different topics I gained in this course, I was disappointed that I had not gained a more technical understanding. This is much more a critique of how much Professor Anisfeld was asked to, or chose to cover, rather than his actual teaching abilities which I found to be quite effective.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Groups working together on problem sets helped reach common understandings.
N/A
The "work group" was simply a recurring study group. It was valuable, but I'm not sure if that's the point of this question...
Group work was not required by the class. I worked with other students on the homework problems and it was helpful for filling in gaps and accuracy-checking.

I consistently worked on the homework with three other classmates and I found this to be very helpful and enjoyable. I feel that we learned a lot from teaching one another and talking through the material together.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Go to the office hours for help with problem sets -- they are far more approachable once you get additional guidance from TAs and professor.
Don't get overwhelmed by the number of graphs and charts.Oh and also, don't forget about sig figs.
Don't get intimidated by the math part of the course!
At least go shop it to see if it's for you. Very good course to take.
Keep up with the readings, especially towards the end of the semester.
Give yourself a lot of time to study for the midterm and final. A lot of material is covered, and you will need to spend a lot of time to review it all.
Definitely helpful for an overview of physical science.

Go to office hours!! For one youÂ´re guaranteed to lose points on the psets if you donÂ´t, but also they are super helpful. For the exams make sure you can do the psets without any outside assistance and you should be in good shape.
Take it.

Be aware that attending office hours is critical to your success and that it is often not possible to complete the homework without attending the office hours or speaking to someone who had. There is occasionally material on the homework that was not really covered in class.
